entry.title: Stephen Fry on Star Trek, Douglas Adams, and More
entry.content: I could listen to Stephen talk for hours on end. Well, I actually did and so should you. First watch this interview, then buy his (audio)book [Moab Is My Washpot](http://www.amazon.de/Moab-My-Washpot-Stephen-Fry/dp/1846572746?tag=lumenlog-21). You're welcome. Permalink

entry.title: Happy Towel Day
entry.content: > A towel, it says, is about the most massively useful thing an interstellar hitchhiker can have. Partly it has great practical value. You can wrap it around you for warmth as you bound across the cold moons of Jaglan Beta; you can lie on it on the brilliant marble-sanded beaches of Santraginus V, inhaling the heady sea vapors; you can sleep under it beneath the stars which shine so redly on the desert world of Kakrafoon; [...] You haven't read The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy? Go do it now. Permalink

entry.title: How to Stop Worrying and Learn to Love the Internet
entry.content: About ten years ago, one of the smartest, most brilliant writers I know died, leaving behind words that make me smile, think and just bow with respect for utter genius. This essay has been linked to quite a bit in the last few days, mostly because it so accurately describes the media's attitude towards the Internet. He wrote that in 1999, and (sadly) it's still true. Permalink

entry.title: How to Stop Worrying and Learn to Love the Internet
entry.content:
We are natural villagers. For most of mankindâ€™s history we have lived in very small communities in which we knew everybody and everybody knew us. But gradually there grew to be far too many of us, and our communities became too large and disparate for us to be able to feel a part of them, and our technologies were unequal to the task of drawing us together. But that is changing.
Douglas Adams. Ein Artikel von 1999, und immer noch so wahr. Ah, Douglas Adams. Solid gold, even though the piece is from 1999. Permalink
